edu.up.cs301.game.util
Class GameTimer

java.lang.Object
  edu.up.cs301.game.util.GameTimer

public class GameTimer
extends java.lang.Object

A GameTimer is an object that sends a GameTimerAction to a Game or a Player at regular intervals. It can be used, for example, in games where players have deadlines for performing certain actions (e.g., chess clock, 24-second clock in a basketball simultation).

Each LocalGame, HumanPlayer and ComputerPlayer has a GameTimer created for it when the object is created. If one of these entities needs to have a "tick" at regular intervals, the will typically execute code such as: 

   // set timer to go off every 100 milliseconds
   getTimer().setInterval(100);
   getTimer().start();
then its 'timerTicked()' method will be invoked every 100 milliseconds; it can then perform whatever time-related operations it wishes to perform.

If additional timers are required, they must be explicitly created, and then handled as a TimerAction (in the checkAndHandleAction method) or TimerInfo (in the receiveInfo method).

Version:
July 2013
Author:
Steven R. Vegdahl

Method Detail

setInterval

public void setInterval(int interval)

start

public void start()
Starts the timer. Has no effect if the timer is already running.

stop

public void stop()
Stops the timer.

getTicks

public int getTicks()
The number of GameTimerActions sent to the game since the timer was started, or since the last reset was performed on this GameTimer.

Returns:
if a reset had been performed, the number of ticks since the most recent reset; otherwise since the object was created.

reset

public void reset()
Resets the timer's tick-counter to zero.
